newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS-Wheat hovers near $4/bushel as U.S. warns EU.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Wheat hovers near $4/bushel as U.S. warns EU.

text.p: Falling wheat prices hovered perilously close to four dollars a bushel for the first time since June on Monday as the United States pleaded with Europe not to engage in a damaging subsidy war.
Prices, which only six months ago hit a record of $7.50 a bushel, have slumped as farmers continue to reap big harvests and competition heats up between exporters, analysts said.
"Prices are falling because a lot of exports are getting done quietly by Australia and Canada. They are fighting for business," a leading European Union grain exporter said.
Benchmark Chicago Board of Trade wheat futures for December fell 6.25 cents to $4.04-3/4 on Friday. On Monday electronic dealing screens in Asia were showing a further loss to $4.03.
In dollars per tonne paid by importers, that equates to $159 a tonne compared with a record near $300 in April when markets were panicked by a drop in stocks to 20-year lows.
Bumper harvests in western Europe, to be followed soon by hefty crops in Argentina and Australia, have made the world's benchmark price traded in Chicago seem expensive to buyers.
Argentine wheat is currently quoted at $143 a tonne.
Traders said much now depended on how the United States and European Union managed to weather the extra price competition.

The trading powers on both sides of the Atlantic, still nursing wounds from a 1980s subsidy war, have so far avoided a new brawl for market share by maintaining a premium over wheat from other origins.
But the United States voiced new worries on Sunday that the EU might undercut U.S. farmers and compete head-on with Argentina for sales by using subsidies.

"We would consider that fairly aggressive," Agriculture Undersecretary Gene Moos told Reuters during a visit to a Paris food fair. Such a step would force Washington to consider restoring its own subsidies to protect its farmers, he said.

The EU irritated Washington by bringing back limited wheat export subsidies last month after a 16-month pause while prices boiled. But it appears to have smoothed relations for the time being by pledging not to undercut U.S. wheat.
Domestically, however, pressure is piling on EU authorities in Brussels to sell the near-record EU wheat harvest of 90 million tonnes more actively or face an internal price slump.

"If they are not more aggressive we will see the price fall and five or six million tonnes will go into intervention," one exporter said, referring to the EU's costly storage mechanism for wheat when it falls below guaranteed support prices.
EU analysts say the European Commission, which effectively markets all grain from the 15-nation bloc, is anxious not to see its silos filled with another unwanted "grain mountain".
That would wipe out hard-won farm reforms designed to make farmers less dependent on storage while also straining a tight EU farm budget under attack from the cost of mad cow disease.
Countering Argentine competition would require current EU wheat export subsidies of about $10 per tonne to be trebled and risk provoking a hostile trade reaction from Washington.
To allow itself to export more grain without having to increase export assistance, the Commission has taken the rare step of telling its own farmers to drive down prices at home.
"High domestic prices are holding up EU exports," a Commission source told Reuters in Brussels on Monday.
On the world market, traders said prices were slowly getting into balance but any signs that Brussels or Washington were stepping up subsidies would be a signal for speculators to act.

"There isn't a great deal of scope for prices to keep going down on their own but you have to remember the funds are there," said one exporter. Prices could sway for some months until the progress of next year's crop gave solid new direction, he said.
